channel.title: The New Yorker — Reporting
channel.description: Latest reporting from The New Yorker

item.title: Who My Child Was and Would Be
item.description: When Nat transitioned, I learned that when someone you love changes, you change, too.

item.title: The Runaway Monkeys Upending the Animal-Rights Movement
item.description: A troop of macaques escaped one of the largest primate-breeding facilities in America. Now a strange coalition of uncompromising activists andMAGAloyalists is demanding that all lab animals be set free.

item.title: Joachim Trier Has Put Oslo on the Cinematic Map
item.description: His new film, “Sentimental Value,” is another intimate character study set in the Norwegian capital. His approach to directing is as empathic as his films.

item.title: Hannah Goldfield on Anthony Bourdain’s “Don’t Eat Before Reading This”
item.description: Bourdain was much more than a whistle-blower, even at the very beginning of what would become his second, incredibly significant career.

item.title: David Byrne’s Career of Earnest Alienation
item.description: At seventy-three, the former front man of Talking Heads is still asking questions about what it means to be alive. But now he’s also offering ideas of hopefulness and service.

item.title: What Was the American Revolution For?
item.description: Amid plans to mark the nation’s semiquincentennial, many are asking whether or not the people really do rule, and whether the law is still king.

item.title: Rian Johnson Is an Agatha Christie for the Netflix Age
item.description: The director revived the cozy mystery with “Knives Out.” In a new sequel, can he find his way to the end of the maze?

item.title: Laura Loomer’s Endless Payback
item.description: The President’s self-appointed loyalty enforcer inspires fear and vexation across Washington. What’s behind her vetting crusades?

item.title: The Strange Afterlife of Hilma af Klint, Painting’s Posthumous Star
item.description: As af Klint’s fame has grown, so have the questions—about what she believed, whom she worked with, and who should be allowed to speak in her name.

item.title: Hanif Abdurraqib on Ellen Willis’s Review of Elvis in Las Vegas
item.description: The magazine’s first pop-music critic was never afraid to be overtaken by unexpected delight, even if it came at the expense of some preëxisting skepticism.
